nodes.text: Contact comfort, rather than nursing or food provision, is the primary variable driving the formation and persistence of infant affectional attachment to the mother surrogate in rhesus macaque infants
Drive-reduction theory posits that attachment to the mother is derived from primary drive reduction (hunger, thirst) by association with the mother
An alternative view is that unlearned tactile contact or 'contact comfort' may be an independent primary affectional variable not reducible to feeding-related reinforcement

Method: Constructed two artificial mother surrogates for neonatal rhesus monkeys â€” a soft cloth-covered terry surrogate providing contact comfort and a wire-mesh surrogate providing postural support and nursing but minimal contact comfort

Method: Dual-mother experimental design with feeding manipulated so that in some pairs the cloth mother lactated and in others the wire mother lactated, and automatic recording of time infants spent on each surrogate over long-term testing
Result: Infants overwhelmingly preferred and spent more time clinging to the cloth mother than to the wire mother regardless of which surrogate provided milk
Result: There were no differences in milk intake or weight gain between infants raised on cloth versus wire mothers, indicating physiological nourishment was equivalent across conditions
Result: In fear and strange-situation tests the infants consistently sought the cloth mother as a haven of safety and base for exploration, independent of nursing condition
Result: Emotionality indices (vocalization, crouching, rocking, sucking) were markedly reduced when the cloth mother was present compared with when she was absent or when the wire mother was present
Result: Preference for the cloth mother persisted across long-term retention tests (up to at least 185 days) and showed resistance to extinction despite infrequent contact reinforcement

Result: Control infants not exposed to surrogates from birth initially reacted with fear or indifference to introduced surrogates but within days to weeks developed strong preference for the cloth surrogate, though intensity differed from animals mothered from birth
Claim: Contact comfort functions as an independent motivating agent for affectional responses, serving roles such as a haven of safety and a secure base for exploration
Conclusion: Findings contradict simple derived-drive (conditioning to food) explanations for attachment and indicate that tactile comfort is a primary factor in infant attachment behavior

Claim: Other variables beyond contact comfort (postural support, rocking, clinging mechanics, maternal sounds, visual features of the face) likely contribute to affection and merit further systematic study

Implication / Conclusion: The experimental paradigm with surrogate mothers permits quantitative study of infant affection, maternal deprivation effects, developmental timing, and practical applications for child-rearing practices, suggesting nursing is not necessary for strong attachment
